item.title: Tour de France: day six highlights
item.trailText: Day six saw another big crash, this time involving yellow jersey-wearer Tony Martin
item.standFirst: Day 6, saw another big crash, this time involving the yellow jersey-wearer Tony Martin. The stage was won by Martin's team mate Zdenek Stybar in an uphill sprint in Le Havre. Daniel Teklehaimanot made history on Thursday by becoming the first African rider to claim a major jersey, the King of the Mountains. Chris Froome maintained his lead over his main rivals.

item.title: Tour de France 2015: stage five highlights – in video
item.trailText: The riders faced another difficult day as wet roads and strong winds caused crashes, forcing one of the favourites for the stage Nacer Bouhanni to abandon the race
item.standFirst: The riders faced another difficult day as wet roads and strong winds caused crashes, forcing one of the favourites for the stage Nacer Bouhanni to abandon the race early in the stage. Andre Greipel once again showed his sprinting skills by taking the stage ahead of Peter Sagan and Mark Cavendish. Tony Martin retained the yellow jersey.

item.title: Tour de France 2015: stage five
item.trailText: The best photos from stage five, a 189.5km ride between Arras and Amiens.
item.standFirst: The best photos from stage five, a 189.5km ride between Arras and Amiens. A close sprint finish saw André Greipel cross the line in first place while Tony Martin was shepherded safely home to ensure that the Etixx-Quick Step rider retained the yellow jersey

cards.title: In video / Three riders taken to hospital and others are hurt
cards.rawTitle: Three riders taken to hospital and others are hurt

item.title: Tour de France crash leaves riders injured
item.trailText: Three riders have been taken to the hospital and others are badly hurt after a crash during stage three of Tour de France
item.standFirst: Three riders have been taken to the hospital and others are badly hurt after a crash during stage three of Tour de France. The crash forced William Bonnet and Simon Gerrans to withdraw due to their injuries, while Laurens ten Dam dislocated his shoulder but was treated before jumping back into the race

cards.title: News / Cancellara withdraws after fracturing vertebrae

item.title: Fabian Cancellara withdraws from Tour de France after fracturing vertebrae
item.trailText: Fabian Cancellara has withdrawn from the Tour de France after fracturing two vertebrae in the horrific crash that interrupted stage three from Antwerp to Mur de Huy
item.standFirst:
• Cancellara suffered injury to back during Monday’s heavy pile-up
• ‘This is incredibly disappointing for me,’ says the Trek rider
item.body:
Fabian Cancellara has withdrawn from the Tour de France after fracturing two vertebrae in the horrific crash that interrupted Monday’s stage three from Antwerp to Mur de Huy. It is the second time this year the Swiss cyclist has suffered similar injuries.

In the race leader’s yellow jersey, Cancellara was brought down heavily in a pile-up featuring at least 20 riders 55 kilometres outside Huy and appeared to signal to medical personnel that he was feeling dizzy and could not see properly. He opted to continue racing despite suffering obvious discomfort and grimacing while attempting to stretch his lower back.

Related: Tour de France: stage three crash – in pictures

Immediately after the stage, the rider was taken to hospital where CT scans showed he had fractured his L3 and L4 vertebrae. In March, Cancellara fractured two vertebrae, also in his lower back, after crashing in the E3 Harelbeke, also in Belgium. He was able to finish Monday’s stage but limped home over 11 minutes behind the stage winner Joaquim Rodríguez.

“This is incredibly disappointing for me,” said the Trek rider in a statement issued on Monday. “The team was on a high with the yellow jersey and were very motivated to defend it. We have had a lot of crashes and injuries since the start of the season, and we finally had a great 24 hours but now it’s back to bad luck. One day you win, one day you lose.”

__VIDEO_EMBED_gu-video-457422316__

Cancellara came a cropper in a crash caused in a fall by the FDJ rider William Bonnet, who lost control of his bike after clipping the back wheel of the rider in front of him, bringing down nearly two dozen other riders. Such was the seriousness of the crash that the race director, Christian Prudhomme, felt compelled controversially to neutralise and then stop the race so the many injured could receive treatment.

As well as Bonnet, who also suffered fractured vertebrae, Orica-GreenEdge rider Simon Gerrans, Giant-Alpecin’s Tom Dumoulin and Team Katusha’s Dmitry Kozontchuk were also forced to abandon.

Tuesday’s stage four takes the peloton over seven different sectors of cobbles on the often narrow lanes between Seraing and Cambrai, where many further crashes are predicted. Sky’s Chris Froome remains in the yellow jersey, ahead of Etixx-Quick Step’s Tony Martin.
